title: Placebo-controlled Confirmatory Study of Galantamine (R113675) for Alzheimer's Type Dementia
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of two fixed doses (16mg/day and 24mg/day) of galantamine (a drug for treating dementia) versus placebo for the treatment of patients with Alzheimer's disease.
description_detailed: This is a randomized (study drug assigned by chance), double-blind (neither the physician nor the patient know the name of the study medication), placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of two fixed doses of galantamine (16 and 24 milligrams per day \[mg/day\]) in patients with Alzheimer's disease. The study consists of a 4-week screening period during which all patients will receive placebo, and a 24-week double-blind treatment period during which patients will receive placebo, galantamine 16 mg/day, or galantamine 24 mg/day. For patients receiving galantamine treatment, the starting dose is 8 mg/day and increases at 4-week intervals in increments of 8 mg/day. The primary measures of effectiveness are the change from baseline to the end of the study (week 24) in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Japan cognitive subscale (ADAS-J cog) and the Clinician's Interview-Based Impression of Change plus - Japan (CIBIC plus-J). Safety assessments include the incidence of adverse events, clinical laboratory tests, vital signs, electrocardiograms (ECGs), and physical examination findings. The study hypothesis is that galantamine will be effective in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. Study drug taken orally twice a day.

dropWithdraws.type: Change of patients for CIBIC plus-J

measures.title: Age, Continuous
measures.description: Six participants were excluded from the randomized patients as no evaluation on both ADAS and CIBIC was made after treatment with study medication.

measures.title: Sex: Female, Male
measures.description: Six participants were excluded from the randomized patients as no evaluation on both Alzheimer's disease assessment scale (ADAS) and Clinician's Interview-Based Impression of Change (CIBIC) was made after treatment with study medication.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Japan Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-J Cog)
outcomeMeasures.description: ADAS-J cog is the Japanese version of the cognitive function subscale of the Alzheimer's disease assessment scale (ADAS). This scale is used to detect changes in cognitive function in individuals with Alzheimer disease on the basis of three domains: memory, language and behavior. The minimum score is zero (0) and means well cognitive function. The maximum total score is 70 points, and the larger the score, the more severe the degree of impairment.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population. Last observation carried forward (LOCF) end point.

outcomeMeasures.title: Distribution of Clinician's Interview-Based Impression of Change Plus - Japan (CIBIC Plus-J)
outcomeMeasures.description: CIBIC plus-J is the Japanese version of the Clinician's Interview-based Impression of Change plus the caregiver's input (CIBIC plus). It is a seven-point categorical assessment scale for evaluating the efficacy of antidementia drugs, ranging from "markedly improved" to "markedly worse".
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population. Last observation carried forward (LOCF) end point.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Disability Assessment for Dementia (DAD)
outcomeMeasures.description: Each of the 40 item of the DAD is scored as 1 point= Yes, 0 point= No, or non applicable= N/A. A total score (minimum=0; maximum=40) is the sum of points for each questions converted out 100. Items rated as Not Applicable (N/A) are not considered for the total score. The final score is a percentage that gives an appreciation of global function in activity of daily life (ADL). Higher scores represent less disability in ADL while lower scores indicate more dysfunction.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population. Last observation carried forward (LOCF) end point.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Behavioral Pathology in Alzheimer's Disease Rating Scale (Behave-AD)
outcomeMeasures.description: Behave-AD is a CIBIC plus-J subscale that rates the patient's severity of psychotic symptoms. This four-point scale varies from 0 (=none) to 3 (= serious).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population. Last observation carried forward (LOCF) end point.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Mental Function Impairment Scale (MENFIS)
outcomeMeasures.description: MENFIS is a Clinician's Interview-Based Impression of Change (CIBIC) plus-Japan subscale that rates the patient's severity for mental function impairment. This seven-point scale varies from 0 (= absolutely no impairment) to 6 (=complete impairment).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population. Last observation carried forward (LOCF) end point.

certainAgreement.otherDetails: The disclosure restriction on PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding results for a period as the sponsor requires.

drug: Galantamine (Razadyne) — galantamine hydrobromide; a small‑molecule reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and allosteric nicotinic receptor modulator; tested at 16 mg/day and 24 mg/day
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests galantamine (fixed doses 16 mg/day and 24 mg/day) versus placebo to treat patients with Alzheimer’s disease. Galantamine’s approved and described pharmacology is symptomatic: reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibition with allosteric modulation of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, increasing cholinergic neurotransmission and improving cognition/activities of daily living rather than targeting amyloid or tau pathology. citeturn0search2turn0search0

Act: Key details extracted from the description and sources — drug: galantamine (marketed as Razadyne/Reminyl), dosing shown in trials and labeling as 16–24 mg/day maintenance; comparator: placebo. These references summarize mechanism and the clinical dose range used in placebo‑controlled trials. citeturn1search0turn0search3

Reflect: Classification rationale — although galantamine is a small molecule, its therapeutic intent in this trial is symptomatic cognitive improvement (improving cognition, function, behavior) rather than modifying underlying AD pathology (amyloid/tau). Therefore it best fits the 'cognitive enhancer' category, not 'disease‑targeted biologic' or 'disease‑targeted small molecule'. Supporting literature and label information reviewed. citeturn0search2turn1search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial drug, galantamine, acts primarily by increasing cholinergic neurotransmission — it is a reversible acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor and has been described as an allosteric potentiator/modulator of neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs). This mechanism targets neurotransmitter systems (cholinergic/nicotinic) rather than amyloid, tau, or other disease-modifying pathways. citeturn0search5turn0search2turn0search1

Act: Extracted details from the trial description — drug: galantamine (Razadyne/Reminyl), maintenance dosing commonly 16–24 mg/day in placebo‑controlled studies; pharmacology: reversible AChE inhibition plus nicotinic receptor modulation leading to symptomatic cognitive enhancement (not established as disease‑modifying). Based on these actions, the most specific CADRO category is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search5turn0search4

Reflect: Confirmation and nuance — classification as D) Neurotransmitter Receptors fits because the therapeutic intent is symptomatic cognitive enhancement via cholinergic/nicotinic mechanisms. Note there is some discussion in the literature about the extent and receptor-subtype specificity of galantamine’s allosteric nicotinic effects (some studies report potentiation; others find limited/no positive allosteric modulation at certain human nAChR subtypes), but this nuance does not change the CADRO assignment since the intervention clearly targets neurotransmitter receptors and cholinergic transmission. citeturn0search2turn0search0

Web search results used (key sources): StatPearls: Galantamine summary (mechanism, dosing, symptomatic action). citeturn0search5; PubMed/Acta Neurol Scand/related articles describing galantamine as an allosteric potentiating ligand at nAChRs and AChE inhibitor. citeturn0search2turn0search3; PNAS preclinical study on galantamine effects on nicotinic receptor binding and AChE. citeturn0search1; A 2018 study questioning positive allosteric modulation at some human nAChR subtypes. citeturn0search0
